options: Drugs with opposing actions acting on the same receptor
Drugs with opposing actions acting on different receptors in the same physiological system

questions.question: 33. Chemical antagonism occurs when:
options: Two drugs compete for the same receptor
One drug chemically reacts with another to form an inactive compound
A drug enhances the effect of another
Two drugs produce an additive effect

questions.question: 34. Synergism in drug interactions means:
options: The net effect is equal to the sum of the individual effects
The net effect is greater than the sum of the individual effects
The net effect is less than the sum of the individual effects

questions.question: 35. Potentiation occurs when:
options: One drug, which has no apparent action on its own, increases the effect of another drug
Two drugs cancel each other’s effects
Both drugs produce an effect that is simply additive

questions.question: 36. Addition or summation in drug interactions refers to:
options: The resultant effect being the algebraic sum of the individual effects

questions.question: 37. Displacement of a drug from its plasma protein binding sites can lead to:

An increase in free drug levels with enhanced activity and potential toxicity

questions.question: 38. When two drugs interact at the receptor level, the result may be:
options: An antagonistic effect where one drug blocks the effect of the other

questions.question: 39. A pharmacokinetic interaction involves:
options: Changes in drug absorption, distribution, metabolism, or excretion

questions.question: 40. Understanding drug interactions is important to:
options: Optimize therapy and avoid adverse effects
Ensure drugs are administered at the same time
Increase drug potency without side effects
